oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mermin-Wagner fluctuations in 2D amorphous solids
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Illing, Bernd
Frischi, Sebastian
Kaiser, Herbert
Klix, Christian
Maret, Georg

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Condensed Matter - Statistical Mechanics

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: While melting in two and three dimensions is substantially different, the glass transition in various dimensions is usually described within the same theoretical framework. Computer simulations recently observed fundamental differences in glassy dynamics, depending on dimensionality: orientational and structural relaxation do not appear simultaneously in two dimensions [1]. Comparing experiments from 2D crystals, 2D amorphous solids, and 3D amorphous solids we confirm this separation of time scales in 2D glass. However, using concepts of 2D crystallography we can entirely explain this without changing the microscopic picture of the glass transition. Long wavelength density fluctuations, so-called Mermin-Wagner fluctuations, affect translational degrees of freedom but not orientational ones. Using local coordinates, the difference in the time scales disappear in 2D glass. Furthermore we can demonstrate with computer simulations the logarithmic increase of displacements predicted by Mermin and Wagner: periodicity is not a requirement for Mermin-Wagner fluctuations which conserve the homogeneity of space on long scales.
